another cycas species, cycas lacrimans yielded isopimaran-ol from the megasporophyll lamina; 9alphah-isopimara,15-diene and triacylglycerols from the bark; triacylglycerols, oleic acid, and 1,2-dioleylglycerol from the leaflets; triacylglycerols, beta-sitosterol, and stigmasterol from the petiole and rachis; beta-sitosterol from the roots; and triacylglycerols and beta-sitosterol from the endotesta and sclerotesta.
chemical constituents of cycas edentata c research article int.

chemical investigation of the dichloromethane extracts of cycas edentata led to the isolation of 9alphah-isopimara-7,15-diene , betasitosteryl fatty acid ester , and a mixture of beta-sitosterol and stigmasterol from the bark; and betasitosteryl fatty acid ester, and a mixture of beta-sitosterol, and stigmasterol, from the sclerotesta.

isolation of the chemical constituents of the bark the air-dried bark of cycas edentata (144 g) were ground in a blender, soaked in ch2cl2 for 3 days and then filtered.
isolation of the chemical constituents of the sclerotesta the air-dried sclerotesta of cycas edentata (48 g) were ground in a blender, soaked in ch2cl2 for 3 days and then filtered.

the structure of alphah-isopimara-7,15-diene, was elucidated by extensive 1d and 2d nmr spectroscopy and confirmed by comparison of its nmr data with those reported in the literature for 9alphahisopimara-7,15-diene.

the structure of alphah-isopimara-7,15-diene, was elucidated by extensive 1d and 2d nmr spectroscopy, while those of 2-3b were identified by comparison of their nmr data with those reported in the literature.

this species which occurs along shorelines is declining due to loss of coastal habitat.

we recently reported the isolation of squalene, betasitosterol, stigmasterol, and triglycerides from the sarcotesta; beta-sitosterol, stigmasterol, triglycerides and phytyl fatty acid esters from the endotesta; beta-sitosterol, stigmasterol, triglycerides, and beta-sitosteryl fatty acid esters from the sclerotesta; and beta-sitosteryl fatty acid esters from the bark of cycas sancti-lasallei.

we report herein the isolation of 9alphah-isopimara-7,15diene , beta-sitosteryl fatty acid ester , and a mixture of beta-sitosterol and stigmasterol in about 3.5:1 ratio from the bark; and betasitosteryl fatty acid ester, and a mixture of beta-sitosterol, and stigmasterol, in about 3.5:1 ratio from the sclerotesta of cycas edentata.
ycas edentata of the cycadaceae family is classified as near threatened by the iucn.
